prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UGC 8573
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A typical HIghMass galaxy with an actively star forming outer disk. HI distributes in an extended ring-like structure, resembling the prediction of HI morphology as a result of recent accretion by the SPH simulations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width is the global value, whereas at each of the spatial resolution elements the CO emission is likely to only spread over ~ 30 km s^-1. Therefore, we choose the spectral window resolution as 5.16 km s^-1. We will smooth the spectral to a channel width of 10 km s^-1 to increase the sensitivity. This is comparable to that of the VLA HI maps (7 km s^-1 channel width). Frequency Division mode is requested only for the baseband containing the CO(1-0) line. Time division mode is selected for the other basebands for continuum measurements, so that a data rate limit is not reached. Plus, the spectral window width can easily encompass the full velocity range, given the integrated CO line width (see Table 1).

Chosen angular resolution: 3.5" is selected to be in between those of the pre-existing Halpha and HI maps, in order to compare multi-wavelength data. At the distance of our galaxies (~ 100 Mpc), 3.5" corresponds to 1.75 kpc, being comparable to the linear resolution of similar Kennicutt-Schmidt (KS) relation studies on kpc scales.
LAS: In the case of M100 (at a distance of 16.568 Mpc), the emission in an individual channel of 10 km s^-1 often shows contiguous features up to 60" in their most extended direction. To be conservative, we take this relatively face-on spiral galaxy as an example and scale its LAS value to the distance of the HIghMass galaxies. The LAS values as a result are below the maximum recoverable scale of the main 12-m Array.

Requested RMS: Our science goal hinges on the measurement of CO intensity at low levels in the outer disks (r > 0.5 r_25) of the HIghMass galaxies, so as to trace the molecular gas. Given the star formation rate surface density (Sigma_SFR) as a function of the galactocentric radius (see Fig. 4), the azimuthally averaged log Sigma_SFR drops from -3 (at 0.5 r_25) to -4 Msun yr^-1 kpc^-2 (at r_25). Assuming an H_2 depletion timescale of 2 Gyr, the log Sigma_SFR = -3.5 corresponds to an expected H_2 surface density (Sigma_H2) of 0.63 Msun pc^-2 in the outer disks. For a factor of 1.36 to account for heavy elements and a CO(1-0)-to-H_2 conversion factor X_CO = 2.0 x 10^20 cm^-2 (K km s^-1)^-1, this Sigma_H2 can be converted to a CO line intensity in the outer disk as 0.14 K km s^-1. At each of the spatial element (3.5"), the CO emission is assumed to be spread over 30 km s^-1. The average signal is therefore expected to be ~ 0.048 K, given a smoothed channel width of 10 km s^-1. The desired mosaic sensitivity can therefore detect the Sigma_H2 with S/N ~ 5 on average in the outer disk. The expected flux is averaged in tilted rings. Where the concentrations of H_2 are located in outer disks, the signal will be greater.
Peak flux density: this value is estimated from the IRAM CO(1-0) line flux (see Table 1). The CO disk is assumed to have the same size as in the optical (out to r_25 with the same ellipticity). To be conservative, the emission is assumed to be evenly distributed in all three dimensions, i.e., the CO line is boxcar-shaped with a linewidth equal to that of the global IRAM CO(1-0) line (see Table 1). The quoted S/N shows the average value over the whole disk, whereas the S/N in the outer disk will be ~ 5.
Velocity resolution: the user defined bandwidth for sensitivity calculation is 10 km s^-1, which is sufficient to detect CO emission given its global linewidth measurement. In case there is any narrower features, especially in this face on target, we keep the original data to have a spectral resolution of ~ 5 km s^-1.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UGC 9334
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A typical HIghMass galaxy with an actively star forming outer disk.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width is the global value, whereas at each of the spatial resolution elements the CO emission is likely to only spread over ~ 30 km s^-1. Therefore, we choose the spectral window resolution as 5.17 km s^-1. We will smooth the spectral to a channel width of 10 km s^-1 to increase the sensitivity. This is comparable to that of the VLA HI maps (7 km s^-1 channel width). Frequency Division mode is requested only for the baseband containing the CO(1-0) line. Time division mode is selected for the other basebands for continuum measurements, so that a data rate limit is not reached. Plus, the spectral window width can easily encompass the full velocity range, given the integrated CO line width (see Table 1).

Chosen angular resolution: 3.5" is selected to be in between those of the pre-existing Halpha and HI maps, in order to compare multi-wavelength data. At the distance of our galaxies (~ 100 Mpc), 3.5" corresponds to 1.75 kpc, being comparable to the linear resolution of similar Kennicutt-Schmidt (KS) relation studies on kpc scales.
LAS: In the case of M100 (at a distance of 16.568 Mpc), the emission in an individual channel of 10 km s^-1 often shows contiguous features up to 60" in their most extended direction. To be conservative, we take this relatively face-on spiral galaxy as an example and scale its LAS value to the distance of the HIghMass galaxies. The LAS values as a result are below the maximum recoverable scale of the main 12-m Array.

Requested RMS: Our science goal hinges on the measurement of CO intensity at low levels in the outer disks (r > 0.5 r_25) of the HIghMass galaxies, so as to trace the molecular gas. Given the star formation rate surface density (Sigma_SFR) as a function of the galactocentric radius (see Fig. 4), the azimuthally averaged log Sigma_SFR drops from -3 (at 0.5 r_25) to -4 Msun yr^-1 kpc^-2 (at r_25). Assuming an H_2 depletion timescale of 2 Gyr, the log Sigma_SFR = -3.5 corresponds to an expected H_2 surface density (Sigma_H2) of 0.63 Msun pc^-2 in the outer disks. For a factor of 1.36 to account for heavy elements and a CO(1-0)-to-H_2 conversion factor X_CO = 2.0 x 10^20 cm^-2 (K km s^-1)^-1, this Sigma_H2 can be converted to a CO line intensity in the outer disk as 0.14 K km s^-1. At each of the spatial element (3.5"), the CO emission is assumed to be spread over 30 km s^-1. The average signal is therefore expected to be ~ 0.048 K, given a smoothed channel width of 10 km s^-1. The desired mosaic sensitivity can therefore detect the Sigma_H2 with S/N ~ 5 on average in the outer disk. The expected flux is averaged in tilted rings. Where the concentrations of H_2 are located in outer disks, the signal will be greater.
Peak flux density: this value is estimated from the IRAM CO(1-0) line flux (see Table 1). The CO disk is assumed to have the same size as in the optical (out to r_25 with the same ellipticity). To be conservative, the emission is assumed to be evenly distributed in all three dimensions, i.e., the CO line is boxcar-shaped with a linewidth equal to that of the global IRAM CO(1-0) line (see Table 1). However, a more realistic case is that where the CO emission comes from a rotating disk, and hence at each of the spatial resolution elements the CO emission is likely to only spread over ~ 30 km s^-1. Therefore, the average S/N over the whole disk should be higher than the quoted value here (S/N ~ 8), whereas the S/N in the outer disk will be ~ 5.
Velocity resolution: the user defined bandwidth for sensitivity calculation is 10 km s^-1, which is sufficient to detect CO emission given its global linewidth measurement. In case there is any narrower features, we keep the original data to have a spectral resolution of ~ 5 km s^-1.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UGC 9037
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Inwards streaming motion is detected in HI.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line width is the global value, whereas at each of the spatial resolution elements the CO emission is likely to only spread over ~ 30 km s^-1. Therefore, we choose the spectral window resolution as 5.14 km s^-1. We will smooth the spectral to a channel width of 10 km s^-1 to increase the sensitivity. This is comparable to that of the VLA HI maps (7 km s^-1 channel width). Frequency Division mode is requested only for the baseband containing the CO(1-0) line. Time division mode is selected for the other basebands for continuum measurements, so that a data rate limit is not reached. Plus, the spectral window width can easily encompass the full velocity range, given the integrated CO line width (see Table 1).

Chosen angular resolution: 3.5" is selected to be in between those of the pre-existing Halpha and HI maps, in order to compare multi-wavelength data. At the distance of our galaxies (~ 100 Mpc), 3.5" corresponds to 1.75 kpc, being comparable to the linear resolution of similar Kennicutt-Schmidt (KS) relation studies on kpc scales.
LAS: In the case of M100 (at a distance of 16.568 Mpc), the emission in an individual channel of 10 km s^-1 often shows contiguous features up to 60" in their most extended direction. To be conservative, we take this relatively face-on spiral galaxy as an example and scale its LAS value to the distance of the HIghMass galaxies. The LAS values as a result are below the maximum recoverable scale of the main 12-m Array.

Requested RMS: Our science goal hinges on the measurement of CO intensity at low levels in the outer disks (r > 0.5 r_25) of the HIghMass galaxies, so as to trace the molecular gas. Given the star formation rate surface density (Sigma_SFR) as a function of the galactocentric radius (see Fig. 4), the azimuthally averaged log Sigma_SFR drops from -3 (at 0.5 r_25) to -4 Msun yr^-1 kpc^-2 (at r_25). Assuming an H_2 depletion timescale of 2 Gyr, the log Sigma_SFR = -3.5 corresponds to an expected H_2 surface density (Sigma_H2) of 0.63 Msun pc^-2 in the outer disks. For a factor of 1.36 to account for heavy elements and a CO(1-0)-to-H_2 conversion factor X_CO = 2.0 x 10^20 cm^-2 (K km s^-1)^-1, this Sigma_H2 can be converted to a CO line intensity in the outer disk as 0.14 K km s^-1. At each of the spatial element (3.5"), the CO emission is assumed to be spread over 30 km s^-1. The average signal is therefore expected to be ~ 0.048 K, given a smoothed channel width of 10 km s^-1. The desired mosaic sensitivity can therefore detect the Sigma_H2 with S/N ~ 5 on average in the outer disk. The expected flux is averaged in tilted rings. Where the concentrations of H_2 are located in outer disks, the signal will be greater.
Peak flux density: this value is estimated from the IRAM CO(1-0) line flux (see Table 1). The CO disk is assumed to have the same size as in the optical (out to r_25 with the same ellipticity). To be conservative, the emission is assumed to be evenly distributed in all three dimensions, i.e., the CO line is boxcar-shaped with a linewidth equal to that of the global IRAM CO(1-0) line (see Table 1). However, a more realistic case is that where the CO emission comes from a rotating disk, and hence at each of the spatial resolution elements the CO emission is likely to only spread over ~ 30 km s^-1. Therefore, the average S/N over the whole disk should be higher than the quoted value here (S/N ~ 6), whereas the S/N in the outer disk will be ~ 5.
Velocity resolution: the user defined bandwidth for sensitivity calculation is 10 km s^-1, which is sufficient to detect CO emission given its global linewidth measurement. In case there is any narrower features, we keep the original data to have a spectral resolution of ~ 5 km s^-1.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose Band 3 CO(1-0) line mapping of three galaxies extracted from the ALFALFA HI survey. These HIgh HI Mass (HIghMass) galaxies have M_HI>10^10 Msun and are exceptionally HI-rich for their baryonic mass. It is not clear whether they are in an arrested stage of evolution or whether their huge HI reservoir is a result of recent baryon accretion. In combination with our multiwavelength data, especially the HI maps and Halpha images, the ALMA observations will be critical to study the HI-to-H2 conversion and the H2-based Kennicutt-Schmidt (KS) relation in HIghMass galaxies, so as to track the full process of the conversion from atomic gas to stars through the molecular gas phase. Two of current targets have bright star forming regions in their outer disks. The proposed CO mapping will gather further evidence of gas replenishment via the search of regions that emerge only in HI, but not in CO, perhaps because of newly acquired atomic gas not yet converted to H2. Identified first as a class only by ALFALFA, the HIghMass galaxies represent the local counterparts of the populations which are likely to dominate future studies of HI at higher redshift with the Square Kilometre Array.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
